results.title: A Holiday in South India
results.creator_credit: Jagat Murari, Ezra Mir and Documentary Films of India

results.title: A Hole in the ground
results.brief_description: A pictorial and sound experiment in which there is virtually no subject movement. All movement is relayed by way of camera and sound track. On a ghost train a ghost of a man comes to town. He makes his way to the hub of that town, the gold mine. Working there, he is killed in a cave-in and remains as one of the town’s permanent residents in the cemetery.

results.title: A Hole in one
results.brief_description: An early animated film about a farmer and his attempts to ride his pet goat. Efforts by the local policeman to ride the goat also fail. The goat finally charges at the farmer and butts him head first into the 18th hole, hence the title of the film

results.title: A History of the game
results.creator_credit: Terry Ryan, Ray Marshall and Opix Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Focus on Soccer”.
The first of a seven part series on soccer skills. Traces the history of soccer in England, and in the second half of the film Manchester City’s Mick Channon looks at the basic skills which every soccer player needs. Provides clear explan ations of training drills and relates these to actual match situations. Narrated by Hugh Jones.

results.title: A History of Britain. Eps 12-15
results.brief_description: Final four episodes of the television series presented by Simon Schama on the history of Britain. This video contains the following episodes: “Forces of nature” (1780-1832 approx.) - Discusses the rise of radicalism, republicanism and political revolutions including the French Revolution in 1789 and how close Britain came to having its own revolution. This was a time for intellectuals, the “romantic generation”, of poets like Thomas Paine (The Rights of man) and William Wordsworth and a rediscovering of nature and the environment. It was also a time for women’s rights and emancipist Mary Wollstonecraft (A Vindication of the rights of women). Mary actively engaged in political debate on the social injustices and treatment of women. Also examines the effect of the 1798 Irish Rebellion. “Victoria and her sisters” (1830-1910) - With the advent of the industrial revolution and advancement in technology, particularly in the area of communications, Britain found its social structure being rapidly reshaped. Queen Victoria came to the throne in 1837 and women more than ever before would play a much more dominant role in society and bring about social reform. This was the Victorian era. “The Empire of good intentions” (1830-1925 approx.) - Examines the British Empire, its successes and its failures including the violence and famine which both Ireland and India were forced to endure. For all its good intentions, and leaders such as William Gladstone and Benjamin Disraeli, political justice failed and common humanity suffered. “The Two Winstons” (1910 to the present day) - Reflects on 20th century history in Britain including two world wars, Sir Winston Churchill, George Orwell (author of 1984), the Cold War and where through all these struggles and events Britain stands in today’s world. See: www.bbc.co.uk/history for more information on this series.

results.title: A History of Britain. Eps 08-11
results.brief_description: Continuing the television series presented by Simon Schama on the history of Britain. This video contains the following episodes: “The British wars” (1603-1649) - A time of civil upheaval, turbulance and war between Crown (under the reign of Charles I) and Parliament, where supporters of the King (Royalists or Cavaliers) fought against the supporters of Parliament (Parliamentarians or Roundheads). This led to a divided country and the eventual creation of a new Britain, a republic Britain caught up in a conflict of ideologies of politics and religion and not in individuals. Three quarters of a million lives were lost during these violent times including Charles I who was publicly executed in 1649. “Revolutions” (1649-1689) - Following Charles I’s execution, the puritanical Parliamentarian reformist Oliver Cromwell ruled Britain with an iron fist but this did not quell the religious and political uprisings. With Cromwell’s death in 1658 came anarchy until the restoration of the monarchy with Charles II in 1660. James II of Scotland and his Catholic fervour almost sparked off another revolution until he was deposed by the troops of Dutch King William. The Great Fire of London in 1666 is also covered in this episode. “Britannia incorporated” (1690-1750) - In the 1690s and into the first half of the 1700s England and Scotland’s relationship was not in particularly good shape in light of the Glencoe Massacre in 1692 and the Battle of Culloden in 1746. The Jacobites in Scotland still supported the deposed James II and the country itself was in the grip of poverty and famine. However half a century later England and Scotland forged a partnership based on profit and interest, not God, which evolved into the Act of Union in 1707. “The Wrong empire” (1750-1800 approx.) - Deals with the military might and total domination by Britain in her quest to build an empire - an empire acquired through exploration and daring but also through slavery, exploitation and conflict. Trade flourished, both in commodities and people. Taxation lost Britain the American colonies, but paved the way for dominance in India. See: www.bbc.co.uk/history for more information on this series.

results.title: A History of Britain. Eps 05-07
results.brief_description: Continuing the television series presented by Simon Schama on the history of Britain. This video contains the following episodes: “King death” (1348 to 1500) - Is the story of the Black Death, a disease which killed almost 45% of the English population. Also covers the Peasants Revolt, Richard II’s attempts to quell the revolt, Henry Bolingbroke and the Wars of the Roses. “Burning convictions” (circa 1500 to 1558) - Sees Henry VIII assert himself as Head of the Church of England triggering the English Reformation and the demise of the Catholics. Edward VI and Elizabeth I lead the way for Protestantism and patriotism. “The Body of the Queen” (1558-1603) - Is about two queens, Elizabeth and Mary, Queen of Scots and the rivalry for religious power between them. Intrigue, plots, the Spanish Armada and at the heart of it all, Elizabeth’s dream of a “great Britain” see Elizabeth surviving and Mary executed. See: www.bbc.co.uk/history for more information on this series.

results.title: A History of Britain. Eps 01-04
results.brief_description: Writer and presenter of this epic television series of fifteen episodes, Simon Schama - University Professor at Columbia University in New York, internationally acclaimed for his best-selling books including “Citizens” (1989), “Landscape and memory” (1995) and “Rembrandt’s eyes” (1999) - manages to make what could be a dull and laborious story into a fascinating, informative and historical biography, enriching and expanding our knowledge of the history of Britain from circa 3100 BC through to the present day. Schama uses the art of story-telling, actual locations of historic importance, paintings, stills, artefacts and architecture, superb photography, vivid re-enactments and some of Britain’s ancient and atmospheric landscapes in the production of this brilliant series. This video contains the following episodes: “Beginnings” (circa 3100 BC to 1000 AD) - Covers the 4000 years that precede the Battle of Hastings, including the Roman invasion, the building of Hadrian’s Wall, King Alfred and Anglo-Saxon England. “Conquest” (circa 1000 to 1087) sees the end of Anglo-Saxon England by the Normans, the rise of Anglo-Norman England and King William’s commissioning of the Domesday Book in 1066. “Dynasty” (circa 1087 to 1216) - Tells about the Angevin dynasty with Henry II bringing in a system of laws and civil service after the chaos and carnage of the Conquest. Also features two of Henry’s sons, Richard the Lionheart and John, whose failure encouraged his Barons to publish the Magna Carta. “Nations” (circa 1216 to 1348) - Finds England at the centre of the Welsh, Scots and Irish nations search for identity and independence. Also follows the rise of Edward I as he leads England to war against these nations and begins to develop his own system of empire building. See: www.bbc.co.uk/history for more information on this series.
